turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Internet Key Exchange.
turn.1: What is the Internet Key Exchange?
turn.2: Internet Key Exchange In computing, Internet Key Exchange (IKE, sometimes IKEv1 or IKEv2, depending on version) is the protocol used to set up a security association (SA) in the IPsec protocol suite.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: IKE builds upon the Oakley protocol and ISAKMP.
turn.5: What are some of the features of IKE?
turn.6: IKE uses X.509 certificates for authentication ‒ either pre-shared or distributed using DNS (preferably with DNSSEC) ‒ and a Diffie–Hellman key exchange to set up a shared session secret from which cryptographic keys are derived.
turn.8: In addition, a security policy for every peer which will connect must be manually maintained.
turn.9: Is there any additional information about IKE?
turn.10: The Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) originally defined IKE in November 1998 in a series of publications (Request for Comments) known as RFC 2407, RFC 2408 and RFC 2409: RFC 4306 updated IKE to version two (IKEv2) in December 2005.
turn.11: What did I find to be the most interesting fact about IKE?
turn.12: RFC 4718 clarified some open details in October 2006.
